origination.corpname: University of Michigan. University Health Service.

did.unittitle: University Health Service (University of Michigan) records 1912-1998, 1970-1998
did.abstract: Campus health service for University of Michigan faculty, staff and students. Records include annual reports; collected historical papers; reports of survey findings and questionnaire results on health service related issues; planning documents; and clippings; and photographs.

repository.corpname: Bentley Historical Library University of Michigan

acqinfo.p: Records were received from the University Health Service (Donor no. 4607) beginning in 1968.

accessrestrict.p: The records are open for research.

userestrict.p: Copyright is held by the Regents of the University of Michigan.

prefercite.p: item, folder title, box no., University Health Service (University of Michigan) Records, Bentley Historical Library, University of Michigan

bioghist.p: A campus health service was established in 1912, in response to requests by faculty and students for a student infirmary similar to those already in existence at several other American universities. The University Health Service officially opened its doors in 1913 in a converted residence on the current site of Burton Memorial Tower. The facility was staffed by two physicians (one male and one female), a nurse, and a clerk who responded to the health needs of over 5,500 students. Initially the Health Service provided only ambulatory care with more seriously ill patients receiving in-room house calls or referrals to the University Hospital. In 1921, the Health Service became a unit of the new Division of Hygiene and Public Health and was relocated to the Children's Annex of the former Homeopathic Hospital. The new location offered 20 inpatient beds, as well as space for offices, x-ray, laboratory, and pharmacy services.

Throughout the 1920s the Health Service was expanded to include new services, departments and clinics. Dentistry and surgery services were added in 1923, and a physiotherapy department was opened the following year. Mental hygiene services began in 1927 with a part-time social worker and volunteer psychiatrist. In 1928, the ear, nose and throat, dermatology, and allergy clinics were added to the growing specialized services. A dietitian joined the staff in 1933, bringing the Health Service staff total to nearly 50 members.

In 1939 the current University Health Service building on Fletcher Street was constructed. The new building, occupied in 1940, was specifically designed to meet the particular needs of the Health Service, including 65 inpatient beds. A decade later, the staff of the UHS had grown to approximately 140 employees.
An immunization clinic was established in 1969, and in 1971 the Gynecology/Contraception Clinic was separated from the main medical clinic to meet the health needs of women students.

The 1970s and 1980s saw a move away from inpatient activity toward providing public health information on campus. Ambulatory care continued to increase, but lack of patients forced the closure of the infirmary in 1983. The latter half of the 1980s saw continuing growth of public information programs, including use of the campus computing network. One such program is the Peer Health Aide program, which trains peer educators to deliver programs on substance abuse, nutrition, contraception, and safe sex.
More information can be found at the official UHS Web Site: http://www.uhs.umich.edu

chronlist.head: Directors of the University Health Service

scopecontent.p: The records of the University Health Service (UHS) date from 1912 to 1998, but primarily document the period 1970-1998. The records reflect the programming and educational activities of the UHS, its changes in both physical and organizational structure and its evolution from a tiny student-service provider of emergency care to a multi-department health care facility serving students and university employees in a number of emergency and preventative, and health maintenance capacities.
The UHS collection is divided into nine series: Historical, Memoranda, Programming, Proposals, Publications, Reports, Surveys, Topical, and Visual Materials.

scopecontent.p: The Historical file contains a folder of miscellaneous early documents, which is a small group of the earliest UHS records, including a 1912 "Plan for a University Physician and Infirmary" presented to President Hutchins by the Committee on Investigation of Infirmary Conditions at Other Universities, along other documents pertaining to the genesis of the unit. A few examples of historical summaries from various points in time follows.

Memoranda are communications within the agency to inform staff of policy, procedure and items of interest. Examples include the 1956 founding of a Pharmacy Committee, a 1958 announcement of a new $2.00 per visit student fee, and a 1960 change in pre-registration examination requirements for new students.

Programming details various Health education and outreach activities, including nutritional programs in dormitories, conferences and workshops on relationships, body image, sexual assault prevention, smoking cessation and the development of the peer health aide program.

did.unittitle: Personal Choice: Guide to the Selection of Birth Control 1986-1988
Health Service Peer Educator Multicultural Issues Agenda 1994
"Run for the Health of It" (5k run) 1981-1985
Task Force on Alcohol and Other Drugs 1990-1991

scopecontent.p: Proposals are applications for educational program funding support, submitted to university entities such as the University of Michigan Substance Abuse Center, and public sources such as Washtenaw County. UHS responses to public concern with growing issues, such as alcohol abuses on campus, are reflected. Also included in this series is a 1938 proposal for a new facility, which documents rationale, plans and budgeting for this undertaking. This became the Fletcher St. facility which still houses UHS.

did.unittitle: Proposal and Planning of New Building 1938-1939
Proposal for the Expansion of Health Services to Non-Student Spouses 1972
Cohort Study of Health Care Utilization and Behavior 1981
Healthier Choices: A Worksite Health Risk Management Pilot Program for Housing Division Employees 1990
Fund for the Improvement of Post-secondary Education (FIPSE) Grant Proposal 1993

scopecontent.p: Publications is divided into five subseries: Articles and Academic Publications, Newsletters, Pamphlets and Information Sheets, UHS Procedures, and Miscellaneous.

Articles and Academic Publications comprises a articles about the university health service or written by university health service staff members, including a copy of an article on influenza co-authored by Jonas Salk and autographed by him.

Newsletters comprises a single issue of a 1972 newsletter and issues of a newsletter for students and faculty Good Health News. Researchers interested in UHS's employee newsletter will find it separately cataloged at Fimu B28 H4, while the UHS Bulletin can be found at Fimu B28 H434 B936. (See also separately cataloged items)

By far, the largest subseries of Publications is Pamphlets and Information Sheets, which comprises several generations of topical informational pamphlets and handouts developed by UHS staff. Many of the files contain not only copies of the pamphlets, but documents related to their creation and editing. These pamphlets may be of particular interest to researchers studying changes in public health concerns and health education, particularly with respect to sexually transmitted diseases including HIV/AIDS and contraception.

UHS Procedures includes several documents published by UHS for communicating policies and procedures to staff. Miscellaneous comprises a number of publications that did not fall under one of the other categories, such as a 1972 flyer titled Is Health Care a Rip-Off?

did.unittitle: Philosophy and Mission Statements, no date

scopecontent.p: Reports include UHS monthly and annual reports for much of the 20th century, as well as committee reports, program reviews, and planning and evaluation documents. Some of these have become proposals and actual new projects, and others, such as the 1969 Committee on a New Building Facility, end at the reporting phase.

did.unittitle: Adequacy of Service to Disabled Students 1978
An Analysis of Hygiene Administration and Education at UM 1937
Committee on the Costs of Medical Care 1932

odd.p: (a comparative study of various schools, including UM)

did.unittitle: Committee Report on Long Range Planning for UHS 1971
Health Education at University of Michigan Health Service 1971
Motivational Factors Affecting Patient Attrition in a Weight Loss Program, circa 1982
Personnel Organization Review Medical/Central Campus Division 1979
University Task Force on Student Counseling 1976

scopecontent.p: The Surveys series preserves efforts to assess and measure student health care knowledge, health practices, and patient satisfaction. Most of the surveys are small samples targeting narrow audiences such as peer education audiences, although a few surveys attempt to address campus-wide perceptions and practices on issues such as AIDS.

did.unittitle: Dress and Manner of Health Care Providers 1982
Monitoring of Patient Care at UHS 1981
Student Health Advisory Committee (SHAC) Telephone Survey 1982

scopecontent.p: The Topical files combine special topics, such as guidelines to control infections; files of administrative nature, such as goal statements and organizational charts; extra-organizational documents such as the Student Advisory Committee; and records of particular people and events related in various ways to UHS and its development.

did.unittitle: By-Laws of the Medical Staff of UHS 1982
Floor Plan of Fletcher St. Facility 1987
Health Rights and Responsibilities of Members of the College Community, circa 1974
Rules and Regulations of the UHS 1982

scopecontent.p: The Visual Materials series contains the UHS scrapbook, several historical photographs and various photo records of contemporary health promotion activities. Included is a sequence of 42 photographs taken in 1961 detailing the steps and diagnostic equipment involved in the periodic health examination. An oversize album portrays UHS staff from 1913 to 1956-57. Several copy prints illustrate early student health exams. Prints and negatives portray a health run, and staff (group and individuals) during the 75th anniversary in 1988. The UHS scrapbook contains newspaper clippings depicting people and events from 1967 to 1982. The series also includes an outsize folder of posters that advertise UHS services, including its specialty clinics and drug treatment facilities.
